natural problem: Add $1_2 + 11_2 + 111_2 + 1111_2.$ Express your answer in base 2.
natural solution: We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, when we sum the digits in the rightmost column, we get a sum of 4. Since 4 divided by 2 gives a quotient of 2 and a remainder of 0, we leave 0 as the rightmost digit of the sum and carry 2 to the next column.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z w :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = bin_of_nat 1"
and h1 : "y = bin_of_nat 3"
and h2 : "z = bin_of_nat 7"
and h3 : "w = bin_of_nat 15"
shows  "x + y + z + w = bin_of_nat 26"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $1_2 + 11_2 + 111_2 + 1111_2.$ Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 11010_2
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, when we sum the digits in the rightmost column, we get a sum of 4. Since 4 divided by 2 gives a quotient of 2 and a remainder of 0, we leave 0 as the rightmost digit of the sum and carry 2 to the next column.
 Continuing in this way, we find $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & & 1 & 1_2 \\ & + & & & & 1_2 \\ \cline{2-6} & 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0_2, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{11010_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z w :: nat
assumes h0 : "x = bin_of_nat 1"
and h1 : "y = bin_of_nat 3"
and h2 : "z = bin_of_nat 7"
and h3 : "w = bin_of_nat 15"
shows  "x + y + z + w = bin_of_nat 26"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given the binary representations of the numbers 1, 3, 7, and 15, find the sum of these numbers. The final answer is 26.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of 1)"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of 11)"
and h2 : "c = nat (bin_of 111)"
and h3 : "d = nat (bin_of 1111)"
shows  "a + b + c + d = nat (bin_of 11010)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $1_2 + 11_2 + 111_2 + 1111_2.$ Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 11010_2
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, when we sum the digits in the rightmost column, we get a sum of 4. Since 4 divided by 2 gives a quotient of 2 and a remainder of 0, we leave 0 as the rightmost digit of the sum and carry 2 to the next column.
 Continuing in this way, we find $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & & 1 & 1_2 \\ & + & & & & 1_2 \\ \cline{2-6} & 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0_2, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{11010_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of 1)"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of 11)"
and h2 : "c = nat (bin_of 111)"
and h3 : "d = nat (bin_of 1111)"
shows  "a + b + c + d = nat (bin_of 11010)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Convert the binary numbers 1, 11, 111, and 1111 to their decimal equivalents. What is the sum of these four numbers? The final answer is the decimal equivalent of the binary number 11010.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "bin_of 1 = 1"
and h1 : "bin_of 3 = 11"
and h2 : "bin_of 7 = 111"
and h3 : "bin_of 15 = 1111"
shows  "bin_of (1 + 3 + 7 + 15) = 11010"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Add $1_2 + 11_2 + 111_2 + 1111_2.$ Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 11010_2
 ### Proof
 We can line up the numbers and add just as we do in base 10. For example, when we sum the digits in the rightmost column, we get a sum of 4. Since 4 divided by 2 gives a quotient of 2 and a remainder of 0, we leave 0 as the rightmost digit of the sum and carry 2 to the next column.
 Continuing in this way, we find $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & 1 & 1 & 1_2 \\ & & & & 1 & 1_2 \\ & + & & & & 1_2 \\ \cline{2-6} & 1 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0_2, \\ \end{array}$$so the sum is $\boxed{11010_2}$.
 *)

theorem
assumes h0 : "bin_of 1 = 1"
and h1 : "bin_of 3 = 11"
and h2 : "bin_of 7 = 111"
and h3 : "bin_of 15 = 1111"
shows  "bin_of (1 + 3 + 7 + 15) = 11010"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In binary notation, 1 is represented as 1, 3 as 11, 7 as 111 and 15 as 1111. What is the binary representation of the sum of these numbers (1 + 3 + 7 + 15)? The final answer is 11010.

theorem
fixes a b c d :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 1"
and h1 : "b = 3"
and h2 : "c = 7"

shows  "a + b + c + d = 26"
